intro: Quercus fulva, commonly known as the southern red oak, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern and central United States. It is characterized by its deeply lobed leaves that turn a vibrant red in the fall. The tree produces small, reddish-brown acorns that are encased in a cupule. Quercus fulva typically grows to a height of 30–50 feet and has a broad, spreading canopy. Its bark is thick, flaky, and dark gray to reddish-brown, providing a distinctive appearance.
